i.comments.all: ### n53: just mountain ## d.startdate: The calculation is based on data from Rovdata (https://rovdata.no/). These data are used to run models to estimate how many of the total number of territories are inhabited. The indicator is the estimated number of occupied territories. i.description: The indicator is a composite index (‘lynx equivalents’) for the estimated abundance of lynx, brown bear and wolves per 'large carnivore region', adjusted for their metabolic weights.
i.comments.all: conceptual connections to the (new) harmonised ETs needs to be clarified ### d.startdate: Population estimates of lynx (Lynx lynx), brown bear (Ursus arctos) and wolves (Canis lupus) based on the Rovdata database (https://rovdata.no/), as reported to the Norwegian Nature Index. The number of lynx is estimated as the number of family groups, whereas the number of brown bears and wolves are estimated as the number of individuals.   Lynx: Track and visual observations of family groups classified as "Documented" or "Assumed certain" in Rovbase from 1 October to 28 February, number of family groups estimated using distance criteria (Brøseth & Tovmo 2013). Data before 2014 are not directly comparable with data 2014-. For details, see Mattisson et al. (2020) and https://rovdata.no/.   Bear: DNA analysis (Tobiassen et al. 2011) of excrement and hair samples of suspected bear-origin, as well as tissue samples from dead bears. For details, see Fløystad et al. (2020) and https://rovdata.no/.   Wolf: Combination of tracking on snow, DNA analysis, GPS tracking, wildlife cameras, dead wolves. When the population size is calculated, wolf territory located across the national border is divided (50%) between Sweden and Norway. For details, see Wabakken et al. (2020), https://rovdata.no/ and www.naturvardsverket.se.   Data are available per county (wolf, bear) or predator-region (lynx; previously also per county), but are aggregated per region in the Nature Index (cf. Jakobsson & Pedersen 2020) and here. Data are not based on a statistical sampling: all available observation and monitoring data are used for the estimation of population levels. The data for these predators can be considered comprehensive. For more information, see www.naturindeks.no. ## d.spat.res: used to be 10 yrs before 2010 ## r.dir: n31 & n32 can't be distiguished

i.description: Species richness of threatened forest birds
i.comments.all:
The proportion of threathened breeding forest bird species of all breeding forest bird species may be a better measure of condition. Different types of forests vary a lot in overall bird species richness. The (local) extinction of a thretened species might mean that this proportion will go down. Will this be recorded as an improvement in condition? 
(unit) The number of threatened species (per se) does not seem to be a good indicator (from a directionality perspective). What would this number indicate? Is it better to have a higher number of threatened species? Or is it or worse? (IMHO it is relatively easy to improve the directionality of this indicator: the number of species with some kind of "favourable status" among the species that bred in the given ET (or ET subtype) in 19XX. The calcualtion could be performed separately for each ET subtype (e.g. forest type) if data allow this, and then aggregated for the whole ET (all forest). In countries where there is BD reporting it could be used, in other countries (like NO) other/ national data could be used istead. ((The same goes for the indicators e.5, f.3, h.5 & i.3, which could be harmonised to e.g. "Share of native bird species in a satisfactory status" -- where the idea is to "define" a meaningful metric without tying the title too closely to either of the two the data source (PECBMS vs Art 12 or its underlying MS data, which is often again PECBMS), but feel free to change the wording.)) ###
